Award.AwardTitle: Exciton Dynamics in Perovskite Quantum Dots and 2D Nanoplatelets
Award.AbstractNarration:
Exciton Dynamics in Perovskite Quantum Dots and 2D Nanoplatelets


In this project, funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Tianquan Lian and a team of graduate and undergraduate students at Emory University investigate two emerging classes of nanomaterials. One type of material (an inorganic class of compounds called perovskites) consists of extremely small spherical particles (called quantum dots), where the size of the particle determines how it absorbs and emits light. The other material is a very thin plate, which can be viewed as a structure with only two dimensions (called nanoplatelets), made from various semiconductor compounds. The flow of energy in these materials, in discrete amounts (excitons) can be followed and controlled. These new materials have potential applications in solar energy conversion and nanoscale lasers. Developing efficient and cost-effective solar energy conversion materials is one of the most important scientific challenges of the 21st century. The proposed work will lead to a fundamental understanding of the properties of these materials, facilitating their further development and many potential applications.

Bulk perovskite materials have achieved impressive performance in multiple applications, including highly efficient solar cells (with certified power conversion efficiencies of > 20%) and low threshold lasing. Colloidal perovskite quantum dots offer the possibility to further tune, improve and optimize the properties of these materials through the quantum confinement effect. Colloidal two-dimensional cadmium chalcogenide nanoplatelets, are an emerging novel class of semiconductor quantum well materials with atomically precise thickness. The uniform energy over lateral dimensions of 10s to 100 nm in nanoplateletes suggests the possibility of novel exciton properties, such as the giant oscillator strength transitions effect. These unique properties, differing significantly from zero-dimensional quantum dots and one-dimenisonal nanorods, suggest many novel applications in optoelectronic devices and in solar energy conversion. The proposed studies are aimed at a fundamental understanding of exciton and charge carrier dynamics in these novel materials, which is essential to their development, rational design and improvement. The specific aims of the research plan are: 1) To study how the electron and hole transfer rates from perovskite QDs to molecular acceptors depend on the QD size and anion identity, testing theoretical models for charge transfer from QDs; 2) To examine how the interfacial electron transfer rates from perovskite QDs to oxide nanocrystalline thin films depend on the QD (size and anion) and oxide (TiO2, SnO2 and ZnO), testing current theoretical models of interfacial ET at QD/oxide interfaces; 3) To measure 2D exciton Bohr's radius and exciton center of mass coherent delocalization length of CdX(X=S, Se, Te) NPLs as a function of layer thickness, materials, solvent dielectric constant and temperature, testing the applicability of 2D hydrogenic model for describing excitons in NPLs and the extent of the giant oscillator strength transition effect; 4) To directly image the spatial distribution of excitons in CdSe core-only, type I CdSe/CdS core/crown and type II CdTe/CdSe core/crown NPLs using electron acceptor (TiO2) modified AFM tips, examining how band alignment in NPL heterostructures affect exciton spatial distribution. In addition to the training of graduate students and undergraduate students, the proposed work will lead to the development of new course materials on clean energy at the undergraduate level and broadened participation of under-represented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome

 

In this project, Prof. Tianquan Lian and a team of graduate and undergraduate students at Emory University examined exciton dynamics in two classes of emerging new materials: the perovskite (CsPbX3, X=Cl, Br, I) quantum dots (QDs) and 2-dimensional (2D) cadmium chalcogenide nanoplatelets (NPLs). The research team 1) investigated how the electron and hole transfer rates from perovskite QDs to molecular acceptors depend on the QD size and tested theoretical models for charge transfer for QDs; 2) examined the effect of surface ligands on the interfacial electron transfer rates from perovskite QDs to oxide nanocrystalline thin films; 3) measured 2D exciton Bohr’s radius and exciton center of mass coherent delocalization length of CdSe NPLs as a function of layer thickness, solvent dielectric constant and temperature, testing the applicability of 2D hydrogenic model for describing excitons in NPLs and the extent of the giant oscillator strength transition effect; 4) Developed a model for optical gain in 2D NPLs; 5) measured biexciton Auger recombination rate for perovskite 1D nanorods and 2D nanoplatelets and developed a model for describing the size and morphological dependence of these rates; 6) Investigated triplet energy transfer in QD/molecule complexes.  

 Intellectual Merit. Bulk perovskite materials have achieved impressive performance in multiple applications, including highly efficient solar cells (with certified power conversion efficiencies of > 20%) and low threshold lasing. Colloidal perovskite nanocrystals offer the possibility to further tune, improve and optimize the properties of these materials through the quantum confinement effect. This project advances the understanding of the charge transfer and biexciton Auger recombination properties in these perovskite nanocrystals, which provide important guidance for the application of these materials in solar cells and light emitting devices.  Colloidal 2D cadmium chalcogenide NPLs, are an emerging novel class of semiconductor quantum well materials with atomically precise thickness of a few CdX (X=S, Se, Te) layers. This project reveals that with uniform energy over lateral dimensions of 10s to 100 nm, NPLs leads to multiple novel 2D exciton properties, such as the giant oscillator strength transitions (GOST) effect, long multiple exciton lifetime, and low lasing threshold. These unique properties, differing significantly from 0D QDs and 1D nanorods, suggest many novel applications in optoelectronic devices and in solar energy conversion.

Broader impact. The findings of this research project have deepened the fundamental understanding of excitons dynamics in low dimensional materials and charge transfer from LHP nanocrystals. These findings also provide guidance for the design and optimization of light emitting, lasing and photocatalytic devices that are based on these materials, which have broader societal impacts. The research team also actively participated in outreach and education programs that aim at broadening research participation of undergraduate students. Through SURE (Summer Undergraduate Research Experience) and SIRE (Scholarly Inquiry and Research at Emory) programs, three Emory undergraduate students have become regular member of the research group. Two undergraduate students, are coauthors of three manuscripts. By partnering with National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBOCChE) and the Initiative to Maximize Student Development (IMSD), the team have successfully recruited an underrepresented minority student into their research group. The research group has participated in several outreach activities, most notably the Chemistry Carnival held annually to celebrate the Atlanta Science Festival.
